none: Letter to Mrs. McInnis from R. H. G. (Mrs. F. A. Gulley), July 31, 1890
Letter to Mrs. McInnis from R. H. G. (Mrs. F. A. Gulley), July 31, 1890
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header] TEXAS Agricultural ✢ Experiment ✢ Station, Agricultural and Mechanical College. | STATION STAFF. | BOARD OF CONTROL. | | :--- | :--- | | F. A. GULLEY, M. Sc. Director. | BOARD OF DIRECTORS, | | G. W. CURTIS, M. S. A., Agriculturist. | Agricultural and Mechanical College. | | H. H. HARRINGTON, M. Sc., Chemist. | EXPERIMENT STATION COUNCIL, | | T. L. BRUNK, B. Sc., Horticulturalist. | L. L. McINNIS, | | M. FRANCIS, D. V. M., Veterinarian. | Chairman of Faculty. | | W. WIPPRECHT, B. S. A., Asst. Chem. | T. M. SCOTT, | | D. ADRIANCE, Asst. Chemist. | Agent of the Board. | | J. W. CARSON, Asst. to Director. | F. A. GULLEY, | | J. M. CARSON, Asst. to Agriculturist. | Director of the Station. | | C. K. FUQUA, B. Sc., Sugar Chemist. | | | HARLEM, FORT BEND CO. | |

ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO EXPERIMENT STATION.

College Station, Texas July 31st 1890 My dear Mrs McInnis,
Your very kind letter came
yesterday, I suppose about the same time you
received mine, I must just write you a line to
tell you what Mrs Bringhurst said last night
I intimated to her that I knew about your
conference and she says "tell Mrs McI that I
have written nothing for the papers, for the
reason that Mr McI has given me no statement
and I understood her that I was not to come out in
public without his consent, but I induced Major
B_ to go and see Cavitt - and Mr. B_ thinks
that Cavitt could be won over - but Mr Adriance
could not." and just about here she remarked
that it was the poorest thing for the College when
Mr Adriance and his father were retained, the one
on the Board and the other in College.
Perhaps you know of Mr Harrington's getting up a paper
asking for Mr McI to be retained, that Major B_
sent with a letter to Major Rose, and Major B_ tells
his wife that he has rec'd an answer to that letter
and that there is a gleam of hope in it for Mr
McI_ now that differs seriously with a letter your

**Comprehensive Transcription Thought Process** Alright, let's break down this transcription. First, I need to understand the task: I'm a professional transcriber, my job is to accurately reproduce the text from this image. The guidelines are pretty specific: top-to-bottom, left-to-right, preserve everything including spelling and punctuation, and use "[?]" for uncertain characters. I need to use Markdown tables and only those specific HTML tags that were provided. The main constraint is that I can only provide the transcribed text. Now, let's analyze the source: it's a handwritten letter on official letterhead from the "Texas Agricultural Experiment Station." It seems like a letter about internal politics or personnel at the station. There is a header, and two sidebars - one with Station Staff, and one with the Board of Control. The date is "College Station, Texas July 31st 1890". The handwriting is cursive and a little faded, so careful deciphering is required. The content appears to be a personal/professional letter to "My dear Mrs McInnis" regarding "Mr McI", "Mrs Bringhurst", "Major B", "Cavitt", "Mr Adriance", "Mr Harrington", and "Major Rose". I will do this in stages. First, I need to transcribe the header. The header includes the name of the station, which is large and center. Then a title and address. Then the sidebars, which I will present in Markdown tables. Then the date line. And finally, the body of the letter. So let’s start with the header section: the visual structure of the document suggests a top-down, left-to-right approach, but the image is a bit complex. The title is "TEXAS, Agricultural Experiment Station, Agricultural and Mechanical College". Then below that is the address line. Then the sidebars. I'll arrange the header in a Markdown table. Now for the sidebars. The left sidebar lists the Station Staff, and the right sidebar lists the Board of Control. I’ll make separate Markdown tables for them to preserve the formatting from the image. Next, I need to transcribe the date: "College Station, Texas July 31st 1890". It's mostly printed, but the "July 31st" and "90" are handwritten. Finally, I’ll transcribe the body of the letter. I’ll go through it line by line, paying close attention to the handwriting. I’ll note my mental draft first and then refine it. It seems to have a good deal of internal discussion. There are some names and abbreviations, like "Mr McI," "Major B," and "Cavitt" that need careful attention. I will use the staff and board lists for any clues on the names. Let's begin: The salutation is "My dear Mrs McInnis". The first part of the letter talks about a "very kind letter" and then details a conversation between the author and "Mrs Bringhurst" about "Mr McI". Then something about “Major B” and “Cavitt” and “Mr Adriance” and “Mr Harrington” and “Major Rose.” The letter seems to trail off at the bottom. I will double-check the handwriting: "Mrs McInnis" looks right, given that it's addressed to Mrs. McInnis. "Mrs Bringhurst" looks right. "Major B" seems clear. "Cavitt" is legible, and "Mr Adriance" is also clear - it's on the staff list. "Mr Harrington" is also on the staff list. "Major Rose" is the President of the board. Now, let's re-format this and ensure I'm using the HTML tags to structure the document. Based on the guidelines, I can use `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, and `sup`. The Markdown table will take care of the sidebars. The "TEXAS" is probably best in `` for bold. "and" in the header will be ``. The handwritten parts of the date will be ``. I'll use `br` for line breaks inside the paragraphs to maintain the visual layout. I’m also seeing a specific request to "Preserve line breaks," so I’ll be careful to keep all the original line breaks in the text. I’ll add `
` tags to make sure the breaks are rendered. Now, I will work on the final construction, piece by piece, incorporating all the formatting and HTML. I'll put the "TEXAS" header first, then the table for the staff/board, and then the address, and the date. Finally, I will transcribe the body of the letter. I'll double-check

Husband had lately from Major Rose, saying that
"the Board" considered his chair vacant, plague
take them, Mr Gulley saw Major Rose this
week and he told him a man by the name
of Pritchard, I believe of Huntsville, had the ch. of Mathematics
I dont suppose Major B- is very confidential or
truthful to his wife, and I have no confidence
in him when he says he would like to have
Mr McI_ back, I think he desires it about as
much as our neighbor at the end of the row
would like to see Mr G. remain. You know
exactly how Mrs Bringhurst talks and goes
on, she said beautiful things about you and
Mr McI_ and about us and I think with you
that she feels badly and wishes the matter
could be adjusted, but it cannot and we
must bear it. You have every thing to
be rejoiced over. It is no come down for Mr
McInnis, to be made Vice President, and Teller,
of such a bank as the one in Bryan, and
you will realize it when he gets to work &
his mind runs in a different channel, and
then he is so near, he can get even with
those men that have been so influential in
undermining him. I am so glad for you
I wish we were as fortunate. Our fate is
still undecided. We probably go to Tennessee.

**The Transcriptionist's Inner Monologue** Okay, here's the task: I need to transcribe this handwritten letter, preserving its original form and formatting. I'm a professional, so accuracy and attention to detail are paramount. No markdown tables, just HTML tags. Right, let's dive in. The image shows a cursive letter, likely from the 19th or early 20th century. The paper is old and creased. Based on the mention of "Major," "Vice President," and a "bank," it certainly seems old. The handwriting is flowing, but legible enough. Time to get to work, line by line. *Line 1:* "Husband had lately..." Yep, that's what it looks like. Let's make sure it's capitalized. *Line 2:* "the Board" looks like it's quoted. "plague,"... that's a bit harsh but seems to be the word, and likely an idiom. *Line 3:* "Mr Gulley" and "Major Rose," here we go. It flows, so far. *Line 4:* "week"... or "walk"? No, considering the context, it must be "week." *Line 5:* "Pritchard, I believe, of Huntsville". This looks like an insertion. Need to tag that. "ch. of Mathematics" - short for chair, I presume. *Line 6:* "Major B- is"... Hmm, there's a superscript B- over 'is'. Is that "Rose" badly written? It's really hard to tell but it looks like a "B-". *Line 7:* Simple enough. *Line 8:* Still going. *Line 9:* "Mr McI_" (dash at the end). *Line 10:* This is progressing. *Line 11:* "Mr G." (Gulley, again), and let's go. *Line 12:* Mrs Bringhurst. No problem. *Line 13:* Smoothly. *Line 14:* "Mr McI_," again. *Line 15:* Context is slowly emerging. *Line 16:* Bear it, okay. *Line 17:* "every thing," two words. *Line 18:* No "come down". *Line 19:* "Vice President, and Teller, Mr McInnis" (full name!), and so on... *Line 20:* In "Bryan," that is. *Line 21:* "gets to work &"... an ampersand, I see. *Line 22:* "runs in a different channel," got it. *Line 23:* This letter... sounds like it may not be great news for someone. *Line 24:* Those influential men. *Line 25:* Glad for you. *Line 26:* Wish we were as fortunate. *Line 27:* "Tennessee", with a capital "T". Right, now the transcription is done. Time to format it correctly in HTML. Need to add the `

` tags and `
` for the line breaks. That insertion is important, so let's use ``. "Major B-", the superscript needs to be there. And "Mr. McI_". And that's all. Double-checking, and let's go. Okay, one last look, and here's the result.

| | | | | :--- | :---: | :--- | | STATION STAFF.
F. A. GULLEY, M. Sc. Director.
G. W. CURTIS, M. S. A., Agriculturist.
H. H. HARRINGTON, M. Sc., Chemist.
T. L. BRUNK, B. Sc., Horticulturalist.
M. FRANCIS, D. V. M., Veterinarian.
W. WIPPRECHT, B. S. A., Asst. Chem.
D. ADRIANCE, Asst. Chemist.
J. W. CARSON, Asst. to Director.
J. M. CARSON, Asst. to Agriculturist.
C. K. FUQUA, B. Sc., Sugar Chemist.
HARLEM, FORT BEND CO. | 1890, July 31st
TEXAS
Agricultural Experiment Station,
Agricultural and Mechanical College.
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO EXPERIMENT STATION. | BOARD OF CONTROL.
BOARD OF DIRECTORS,
Agricultural and Mechanical College.
EXPERIMENT STATION COUNCIL,
L. L. McINNIS,
Chairman of Faculty.
T. M. SCOTT,
Agent of the Board.
F. A. GULLEY,
Director of the Station. |

College Station, Texas..................................................................18........

We have the choice, Virginia & Tenn, for the
chair of Agriculture, not quite what Mr.
G. wanted. The University of Tenn, College we consider
on a better footing than the one in Va.
and for that reason prefer it, but we have
to hear again from there before we decide.
The Whitlocks are getting anxious for the
house. I was furious, when they enquired of Mr
G. yesterday about it, but on reflection, I think they
fear the Board will meet again, and will
not let them have the house, unless they are
in it. So I shall tell Mrs W when I go to
mail this letter, if they want to move in now
they can, It will not be so pleasant for either
party, but I am willing to put up with it, if
they are. Mr G. is in Dallas -
It pleases me very much that Malcolm
and Lila Graham remember me - and I hope
you will not let them forget me. It is too bad
that we must be separated, I wonder if this is
my fate, to go around the world, making friends

**Transcription Thoughts**

Okay, here’s how I’m approaching this transcription task, as a seasoned professional. I need to take this image of a letterhead and text and transform it into a perfectly accurate, well-formatted transcription. First, I’m breaking the whole thing into a few key steps. I start by analyzing the requests and understanding the constraints. Then, I dive into the image itself, looking closely at every detail. The letterhead is elaborate, with columns of information, a handwritten date, and a dateline. The handwriting itself will be the biggest challenge, but I'm ready to tackle that, taking it line by line.

I'm thinking to structure the transcription in distinct blocks. The layout needs to be precise, preserving the original formatting and any handwritten details. I am aware of the correct HTML tags to label the structural elements. My goal is to capture everything accurately – spelling, punctuation, capitalization – while respecting the original text. I'll need to use Markdown tables for lists, like those in the header section.

Next, I'm carefully transcribing the image, keeping a close eye on the handwriting. I am noticing there are a few interlineations that must be captured. The letter uses a late 19th-century cursive style. While generally legible, some words are tricky. I'll need to make use of `[?]` and `[illegible]` where needed, and note marginalia with `[Margin: text]`.

Then, I'm putting it all together. I'm taking the header columns and rendering them into an HTML-compliant format. For the tabular data, I'm going to follow the instructions to use Markdown tables. The most complex part is capturing the relationships between the columns. I'll check my HTML, and Markdown to make sure it's valid.

As I'm transcribing, I'm going to double check for handwriting specifics, like that handwritten "1890, July 31st" and the word "College" written under "Tenn". I'll format insertions using `<sup >` and `<sub >` tags to keep track of that. I am re-evaluating each word and punctuation mark, taking into account the context and my best interpretation. I'm focusing on the overall flow of the text.

I'll finalize it by checking against constraints, like correct HTML, spelling, and punctuation. Any ambiguous or tricky parts, I will double-check. The image looks reasonably good. I'll be sure the transcription is accurate and readable. All that remains is to format it properly. I will make a table for the header info.

I'm making sure it's perfect, checking every detail and putting it into the final output. The main goal here is a clean, accurate, and completely faithful transcription.

and parting with them, I dread it so much,
starting in again, and Knoxville will not
be like going to a College Campus. I don't
suppose they feel obliged to call cultivate on the
Prof- wives, especially as they have other
society, and I expect to be very lonely for
a while, You see, my dear, the advantages
you have, you are known and thought
much of. I am wondering what you will
do about Ch, can you sit in the same
house with Major Cariel and worship.
But I must hurry or I will not be in
time for the mail, I am so glad for
you, that you have got to a haven of
rest, where there are plenty of rocking
chairs, and now you must cheer up, and
dwell upon your blessings past and
present. the future has every thing for you
Love to your Father & Mother and kisses for
the children, and write soon again to
me your friend B.A.G. [Mrs. F.A. Gulley ?]
I have not seen Mrs Curtis, but am sure if Larthin
Lamas husband was not very sick in bed here, she would
have worked some scheme to have gotten her, Mrs Hayes drags
[Margin: out the chairs every night. which always excited my risibles -]

**Transcription of the Handwritten Letter**
